Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 03:19PM glow wrote: Please take the time to check out our web site side-out.org.  My son started this organization in order to try to help me when I was diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer.  It is through the sport of volleyball we were able to raise enough funds to do a small clinical trial for only metastatic women.  During the month of October we raise funds throughout the country with what is called a Dig Pink Rally, volleyball tournaments.  Mostly girls in high school and colleges.  Since I am a metastic person I am very interested in what you are doing to get more research in this particular arena.  We should link up our web sites.  If you want more information you can contact my husband Bryant at 703-615-8740.  He is the project manager of what is referred to as the Side-Out Protocol.  It hasn't started yet but we expect in the next month or so it will.  Thanks for what you do.  More work needs to be done in finding kinder drugs and alternatives for us who are living with this disease.
Posts.Title: Let Our Voices Be Heard in October gracem glow

Posts.Content: glow wrote: I have been fighting Metastatic Breast Cancer for nearly 6 years and it's been quite a journey!  I have bone, skin and liver mets.  When I had the reoccurrence my son started a foundation called Side-Out where we raise funds through the sport of volleyball.  Side-Out is presently funding a 2 year clinical trial just for Metastatic Breast Cancer patients who have had at least 3 drug failures.  The goal of this trial is to identify at the cellular level a particular drug that will target your particular tumors. Additionally there will be another lab studying your cells for proteins that feed the Cancer.  Each person in the trial after both reports are in will be put on the drug or drugs that the reports indicate will work with your tumors.  For more information on the  trial check out our website side-out.org.  I am in the trial and presently awaiting the results of my testing.  The metastatic cells are very smart and they find ways of averting the chemo.  We are hoping through this trial the scientists will better understand how these cells work plus giving the patient more options to manage their disease.
